title: 109_hr5939
content: The Act may be cited as the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" and includes provisions related to terrorist offenses resulting in death. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces a new offense under Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, for terrorist offenses resulting in death. This offense applies to individuals who cause the death of a person while committing a terrorist act and carries a penalty of death, life imprisonment, or a term of years. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces a new offense under Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, for terrorist offenses resulting in death. This offense applies to felony offenses that are Federal crimes of terrorism or attempts/conspiracies to commit such offenses. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces a new offense under Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, for terrorist offenses resulting in death, with the possibility of the death penalty for certain terror-related crimes. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces amendments to various sections of the United States Code, allowing for the death penalty in cases where death results from offenses related to nuclear weapons, missile systems, atomic weapons, and radiological dispersal devices. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends sections of the United States Code to allow for the death penalty in cases involving nuclear weapons, atomic weapons, radiological dispersal devices, and the variola virus. SEC. 4 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" increases penalties for certain offenses by amending the United States Code to extend prison terms. For example, the amendment changes the sentence from "20 years" to "30 years" for Section 2332(b)(1) and from "10 years" to "20 years" for Section 2332(c). Additionally, Section 2339C(d) sees similar adjustments in prison terms from "20 years" to "30 years" and from "10 years" to "20 years". SEC. 5 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" updates the state of mind requirement for Section 2339C offenses by replacing "unlawfully and wilfully" with "knowingly". SEC. 6 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" increases penalties for providing material support to terrorist groups and receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization. Penalties now include imprisonment for not less than 10 years or life, and up to 30 years or life if death results. SEC. 7 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" focuses on denying federal benefits to convicted terrorists. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, to deny Federal benefits to individuals convicted of Federal crimes of terrorism. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, to define 'Federal benefit' and deny it to individuals convicted of Federal crimes of terrorism. The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code to deny Federal benefits to terrorists. Section 2516(q) is amended to change wiretap predicate, and section 2339D is amended to include attempts and conspiracies related to military training offenses.
